title: LLVM link error using ld.gold
body:
I've just had a link error I never had before (last tried 2 weeks back maybe, nothing has changed on my `x86` end) while switching to `ld.bfd` immediately solves the issue:

``` shell
note: /mnt/usr/lib/libLLVMObject.a(Archive.o):Archive.cpp:vtable for llvm::object::Archive: error: undefined reference to 'llvm::object::Archive::~Archive()'
/mnt/usr/lib/libLLVMCore.a(DiagnosticPrinter.o):DiagnosticPrinter.cpp:vtable for llvm::DiagnosticPrinterRawOStream: error: undefined reference to 'llvm::DiagnosticPrinterRawOStream::~DiagnosticPrinterRawOStream()'
/mnt/usr/lib/libLLVMCore.a(Pass.o):Pass.cpp:vtable for (anonymous namespace)::GetCFGOnlyPasses: error: undefined reference to 'llvm::PassRegistrationListener::~PassRegistrationListener()'
/mnt/usr/lib/libLLVMSupport.a(FormattedStream.o):FormattedStream.cpp:function llvm::fouts(): error: undefined reference to 'llvm::formatted_raw_ostream::~formatted_raw_ostream()'
/mnt/usr/lib/libLLVMSupport.a(FormattedStream.o):FormattedStream.cpp:function llvm::ferrs(): error: undefined reference to 'llvm::formatted_raw_ostream::~formatted_raw_ostream()'
/mnt/usr/lib/libLLVMSupport.a(FormattedStream.o):FormattedStream.cpp:function llvm::fdbgs(): error: undefined reference to 'llvm::formatted_raw_ostream::~formatted_raw_ostream()'
/mnt/usr/lib/libLLVMSupport.a(FormattedStream.o):FormattedStream.cpp:vtable for llvm::formatted_raw_ostream: error: undefined reference to 'llvm::formatted_raw_ostream::~formatted_raw_ostream()'
/mnt/usr/lib/libLLVMSupport.a(FormattedStream.o):FormattedStream.cpp:vtable for llvm::formatted_raw_ostream: error: undefined reference to 'llvm::formatted_raw_ostream::~formatted_raw_ostream()'
collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status

error: aborting due to previous error
make: *** [i686-unknown-linux-gnu/stage0/lib/rustlib/i686-unknown-linux-gnu/lib/stamp.rustc_llvm] Error 101
```

One interesting part from the linker command line is this:

`"-Wl,-rpath,$ORIGIN/"`

Is there a problem with variable expansion or is it something else about honoring this variable by different linkers?
